Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Student Activity and Learning on Cybersecurity Testbeds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project led by the University of Southern California, in collaboration with Evergreen State College and Lewis and Clark College, aims to develop tools that automatically assess student learning in practical cybersecurity tasks, both for individual students and for the entire class. This is currently a challenge because such tasks are often open-ended and exploratory in nature. Because they can be completed in many ways, student learning in cybersecurity may not always be recognized by the instructor. This makes it hard to assess the sophistication of a student's path to success. Similarly, it may also be a challenge to identify the reasons why students experience failure, and to provide useful and timely feedback to students and instructors. The proposed project work will uncover reasons behind student underperformance in practical cybersecurity exercises, and will help identify effective interventions. The proposed research may also help network test beds retain and better serve their users. The impact of these activities will be three-fold. First, the developed tools will be integrated with two previously developed platforms for cybersecurity exercises: DeterLab and EDURange. This will directly impact approximately 2,000 students annually. Second, the tools will be highly portable to other platforms that use Linux in practical cybersecurity exercises, and can reach a wider audience. Third, the tools will help retain talent from disadvantaged and minority populations, as it will allow for earlier intervention and feedback to complete challenging, practical tasks.

This project will develop ACSLE, a framework for automated assessment of student learning in practical cybersecurity exercises. ACSLE will engage in constant and extensive monitoring of student interaction with the computer, and will allow for the correlation with desired learning outcomes. ACSLE starts with the development of tools that monitor low-level student activities, such as commands typed, traffic generated and files and processes created. These low-level records are then synthesized into high-level indicators of student progress on a given cybersecurity task. The outcomes will allow for: (1) classification of students into several learning styles based on proficiency with a task and level of foundational skill; (2) clustering of solutions to specific learning challenges identified in student groups that have similar learning styles; (3) collection of successful learning paths developed over time and methods for identifying struggling students; (4) identification of causes of failure and delivery of appropriate learning interventions; and (5) aggregation of performance data for a class as well as identification of tasks that are difficult for many students. ACSLE will thus provide useful information for students and teachers, and improve overall learning in practical cybersecurity exercises.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cybersecurity skills are still in critical demand in the workforce. We and others have tried to address this by providing hands-on exercises that help students gain practical skills related to specific learning objectives.  Hands-on exercises are often used to improve student engagement and knowledge retention in systems, networking and cybersecurity classes.

However, hands-on exercises can present obstacles to learning.  We have examined the problem of student under-performance across two different testbeds and have studied why students have difficulty. This problem has not been sufficiently studied in the literature, and we have found that it can be a combination of two factors: if students a) lack some background skills and knowledge or b) are unfamiliar with the exercise environment.

We focused on the first factor: identifying gaps in students' skills and knowledge. This allows instructors to help individual students as well as the whole class if these gaps are shared. In our experience, too few students complete all exercises successfully. They  may not fully comprehend the concepts, such as subnetwork structure, or they may lack some skills, such as the use of nmap.  Instructors need effective tools to identify and distinguish these problems during an assignment and offer targeted and timely help. For our hands-on exercises, students interact through a terminal, and we assess whether a student has understood and completed a task by defining milestones that they must achieve.

We created a system called ACSLE, which contains automated tools for analyzing terminal histories and detecting milestones to enable rapid and continuous assessment of student work.  It produces both summary and detailed statistics of student progress. We analyzed data from undergraduates at several colleges as they performed several cybersecurity assignments on network testbeds. We showed how ACSLE's output can help teachers identify students that struggle, understand why they are struggling, pinpoint frequent error patterns, and offer timely help. ACSLE can also help teachers identify challenging tasks and plan class-wide interventions.

This approach also allows us to alert instructors about the likelihood of student succes early in a student's undertaking the exercise. We used machine learning (support vector machine) to estimate the probability that a student will complete the tasks in an exercise based on their actions early in the exercise.

There is another advantage of this approach. Using automated tools can help retain talent from disadvantaged and underrepresented populations because the tools we develop would not reflect possible hidden biases that the instructor may have.

Our dissemination and outreach approaches have include papers, workshops and demonstrations at SIGCSE and CCSC-NW conferences. This project has also provided opportunities for undergraduate research.
